headline: Who's Talking to Chris Wallace
subHeadline: Comedian And Television Host Bill Maher Is Interviewed On What He Believes Has Changed About Political Right And Left In U.S.; Bill Maher Discusses Donald Trump's Inability To Concede Electoral Defeat And What That Possibly Portends For 2024; Comedian And Writer Larry David Interviewed On Ending His Show "Curb Your Enthusiasm"; Larry David Discusses Final Scene In His Show "Seinfeld". Aired 10-11a ET

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Hello, and welcome. Normally we spend this hour talking about the week's biggest stories with our panel. But on this July 4th weekend, we're doing something different, a special edition of our other show, "Who's Talking" where we sit down with some of the most interesting and entertaining people around. Today you're in for a treat as we bring you conversations with the stars of two of the most popular shows on TV, Larry David, who's unbelievable run on "Curb Your Enthusiasm" recently came to an end, and Bill Maher, whose "Real Time" program goes after sacred cows across the political spectrum.So as we say every Saturday, sit back, relax, and this time, enjoy. (BEGIN VIDEO TAPE) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Does that mean I'm a scene stealer?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In a good way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not famous. I'm well known.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Watching that scene?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's hard to watch.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is this a bit that you're doing for me?

utterances.speaker: LARRY DAVID, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: No, it's not a bit.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Bill Maher, welcome. So good to see you again.

utterances.speaker: BILL MAHER, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: Good to be here at CNN and on CNN. I know I'm on CNN. WALLACEShock You", and it's a collection of your commentaries, your editorials on "Real Time" over the last 20 years. "What did you discover about both how the world and you have changed over that time?"

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, it's interesting you asked that because that's really the impetus to do this. People kept saying to me, well, two things. They kept saying you should really collect these editorials that you do. They're really good at the end of the show. And it is the part of the show I work the hardest on. I probably put 20 hours in to get 10 minutes of content. So these things have been lol tested, shall we say.So to answer that question about myself, did I change? Did the country change? Look, we're all evolving. Of course, I'm sure I've changed to a degree, but honestly, I really look at this hard and I think it's mostly the politics changed.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, let me dig down on the change in politics and we'll take it separately. First the right. How do you think, the conservative movement, the Republican Party has changed since Donald Trump took over the GOP?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, where do I begin? They're authoritarian. They don't believe in democracy. I know we hear that a lot, but it's true. You can't say it enough. I mean, I was using the term "slow moving coup" before he was elected the first time. Everybody made fun of me that I was an alarmist, but I turned out to be right about that.And we see now the sycophants around him, the people who are auditioning for vice president, they've picked step this talking point when they're asked, will you abide by the results of the election? And they say, sure, if it's a free and fair election, which is another way of saying, if we win.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Then there's the left with wokeness and political correctness and, as some of your viewers say, you have taken some shots at them on "Real Time" in recent times.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Lots.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Take a look.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Being woke is like a magic moral time machine where you judge everybody against what you imagine you would have done in 1066 and you always win.Of all the violations of the woke penal code, culture appropriation just might be the dumbest of all. I've seen the same syndrome happen in comedy clubs, woke hecklers who literally have to wait for the laughter to die down before they yell "That's not funny." (LAUGHTER) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You say liberals protect people. PC-ers, woke people, protect feelings.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I forgot that. Thank you.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What do you think it means now?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean the term "woke" was what we used for that. But, well, I mean oversensitivity, victim culture, cancel culture, too much identity politics, just ideas that -- embracing a bunch of ideas that I don't think are very valid. I mean, we are now an outlier, for example, as far as the issue of transitioning children gender-wise. The U.K., the Scandinavian countries, which were always countries which we could look to and say, well, look, they're the liberal places. They're doing this. They're to the right of us on that. I mean, we're to the left of Canada on immigration.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Recently, you have been going after they pro-Palestinian protests on campus which seem to combine two things that you don't have much use for. One, people signing up for a cause they don't really understand, and two, elite education.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, one of the things I'm proudest of in this book is, as I was going through it, all the things where I've been ahead of the curve on something. And one of them certainly was college. I mean, I was saying long ago the Democratic Party's idea is that the more time you sit in a classrooms in front of a blackboard, the better you are, and the more college everybody gets, the better they are. I think that's just antiquated thinking. I don't think it helps anybody and they're not really learning anything. I think we saw that.If I had any doubts that it was the left who had changed more than me, that was settled after October 7th, when I saw so many people standing up, these people who consider themselves liberals, the most liberal people, standing up for the most illiberal people in the world.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Hamas. MAHER

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, this gets me to another interesting part of the book and of your evolution, which is how you describe your place in the public square, because in a world in which everyone seems to pick sides, you're an equal opportunity basher. And the question, I guess, I have, is that lonely? And do you think it's risky?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: It has been lonely at times. There's no doubt I've lost audience, and gained. And the ones I've lost, I don't miss them, because I don't speak for the people who want to be ideologically captured by one side and just want to hear what they already know coming back at them. I think that's the biggest problem we have in the media today. We're all in our silos. We're all in these little bubbles. And they don't even want to hear it. They don't really want to hear the other side.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, well, so I'm going to give you a chance to call it out. What do you say about the other what had been called comic commentators like Jon Stewart.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to talk about other people. I'm not going to do it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, wait.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Good try. It's just, it's a fool's errand. They're all very talented.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I understand they're all talented. But you've just said that we can't just be siloed, we can't just be pushing one thing. You've got folks like Stephen Colbert and John Oliver and Jon Stewart who seemed to have picked a side and toe a party line.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And does that, what's your reaction to that?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I watch my show and your show and that's it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I know I'm not going to get much, but, you know.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: You've got to try. It's your job.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's like waving a piece of meat in front of a pit bull. It's like, oh, he's not going to talk about this. I've got to get him to talk about it.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Look, I have a different place. That's it. I just do a different thing. And there's this room for everybody. And pick your lane.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) [10:13:56] WALLACE: Starting in 2018, you started predicting with some regularity that if Donald Trump lost his bid for reelection in 2020 that he wouldn't leave. Here you are. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He's not going to leave even if he loses the election.I keep saying he's not going to leave, even if he loses. If Trump loses the election in November, he's not going to leave. I cannot picture that man gracefully conceding and walking away. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You also predicted months before he lost that his supporters might well march on Washington. What did you see so far in advance?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So what do you think happens if he loses this time?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, on January 20th, 2025, he's going to show up on Inauguration Aay, whether he wins or loses, because he will claim that he won. That is the one thing I can absolutely predict with utter certainty. He will never, as I kept saying all those years, will never concede an election. He's certainly not going to concede this one.And I don't know, any time you want to be out of the country, that would be the good month to do it, I think. I don't foresee good things happening on my birthday, which is January 20th.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, that's ironic, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, we'll see. WALLACErecently you told Jerry Seinfeld that if he wins, not loses, but wins, you're not going to go nuts again. Here you are. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to lose my nervous system about Trump again. If he ends the world, he's going to end the world. I'm not going to -- go nuts again if he wins another term.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So is it that you think Trump 2.0 wouldn't be as bad, or you just don't care as much?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I care. I just I just am not going to -- I guess maybe I was not saying that artfully. What I'm not going to do is just lose my nervous system at every step of the way. I think he just thinks of power. He just wants to get that back. It's like what the documents that he stole. They were mine. Now I own them. And I touched them, and you can't have them. I mean, there was no reason to it. It didn't make any sense. What did he want them for? Nothing. He was never going to look at them. He's never read anything, more than one sheet of paper at a time. He wouldn't know it was in the Constitution if you hit him over the head with it. This is the guy who is going to be probably president again. So --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think so?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I think it probably odds-on, yes. I mean, he's certainly winning now, and Biden does not look like a very good candidate. So I just, I can't do it again. I can't go through this on a day-by-day basis. that's what I meant by that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So January 20th or maybe Election Day, that's when you lose your mind?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: We could lose a lot more than my mind.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: A couple of final questions. What's the deal would you and pot?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I love it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Why? Have you ever smoked it?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes. We were just talking the talk here in the studio, and we said if you had a good joint or you had a good glass of wine, we chose the wine.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, that's you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I mean, that's it. It's about body chemistry. Some things agree with --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, what is it that you like so much about it?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: People have different reactions to pot. I would say that the three main ones, it can make you paranoid, it can make your sleepy, a lot of people use it for sleep. Or it can make you high. That's why we call it getting high. Some people are that third category. It makes them better. People think I'm a huge pothead or smoke all the time. I don't. I don't even smoke every day. I smoke situationally. What I want to be at my best at something. So that works --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You don't -- are you high now?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So didn't want to be at your best for this?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I can handle this without --(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But what do you mean your best? Do you get high before "Real Time"?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No, that would be too tough, because I have to keep too many things in my mind at the same time. And I'm on with a senator and important people, and I have to watch the clock.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So when --

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Stand up.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Writing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Sex.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: That's my life.(LAUGHTER) (END VIDEO TAPE) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEO TAPE) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LARRY DAVID, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: I've been expecting more from myself my whole life, and it's just not there. WALLACE

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, what the -- Larry?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Ending the latest chapter in a comedy career that started --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That's gold, Jerry, gold.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: As one of the brilliant minds behind --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The show is about nothing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Partnering with Jerry Seinfeld and cementing his place in TV history.

utterances.speaker: JERRY SEINFELD, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: But are you still master of your domain?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No soup for you!

utterances.speaker: SEINFELD
utterances.sentences: Not that there's anything wrong with that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But it's Larry's current act that really put them in the spotlight.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Oh my god, this is awful. Who made that?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Us.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: You made it? I want my dollar back.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: As he stepped in front of the camera to play some version of himself in "Curb Your Enthusiasm."

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It's pretty, pretty, pretty, pretty good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Now, as HBO's longest running series wraps up its final season, we dig into the everyday events that drive him famously crazy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Happy New Year!

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And ask what led him to say goodbye to this TV persona?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: How did I wind up here? How did I wind up here?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Larry David, welcome. It's so good to be with you again.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much, Chris. This isn't going to take very long, right? What are we, like a couple of minutes, five minutes? Because, you know, I don't really sit with people as a rule for a long time. Even dinners -- WALLACE

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: All right, good.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We're coming to the end of season 12 of "Curb Your Enthusiasm," and I've got to say you are on fire. In one episode, you get in a fight with a hotel maid, a waiter who has lost his mother, and even with the Siri device in your car. Here's that one.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Siri, directions to Wolfsglen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Directions to Great Wolf Lodge.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, Siri, Wolfsglen restaurant.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: One option I see, Wood's Garden Supply on Benedict Canyon.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Suri, Wolfsglen restaurant in Westwood.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: One option I see, the Wolseley restaurant in Burbank.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No. No. No. You're not listening.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It gets a lot worse than that.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But in any case, I was going to --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: By the way, that scene, the night that happened, when I was going someplace, and that's actually how I reacted, just everything you see in that scene is what I did. And I came in the next day. I said, listen, we've got to shoot this. This is really funny. And so we did, and we put it in the first show.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why is it that so many things in life, like Siri, trigger you?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I have a very low tolerance for stupidity in myself and in others. And so, I don't know. I just notice things that maybe, I don't know, maybe other people don't. Or I think I just, things impact me more, like -- and I have an outlet to do it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In 2020 in "Curb" you discovered the advantages to wearing a MAGA hat.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All right, two seats at the sushi bar. You know what, actually, I think we'd prefer to sit at a table, please. DAVID(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In your world here, because you live in Beverly Hills or Santa Monica or something like that, what would wearing a MAGA hat do?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'm sure you'd get some very odd looks in Los Angeles if you were walking around with that hat. But yes, I used it on the show, it got me out of a couple of things. I was going to get beat up by a biker. Then I put that hat on.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So how much has the whole 2020 election and everything that has flowed from it pissed you off?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I mean, you can't go a day without thinking about what he's done to this country, because he's such a little baby that he's thrown 250 years of democracy out the window by not accepting the results of -- I mean, it's so crazy. He's such a sociopath. He's so insane, he just couldn't admit to losing. And we know he lost. He knows he lost. And look how he's fooled everybody. He's convinced all these people that he didn't lose. He's such a sick man. He is so sick.Anyway, no, it hasn't impacted me at all. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How do you wrap your head around the fact that he could very well be reelected president? I mean, right now, I'd say he he's the favorite.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: He's just such an amazing conman. He has such a gift for lying and fooling people and convincing people of something that's a complete lie.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But the fact, but the point is millions and millions and millions of Americans, more so than three years ago, they buy it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: They buy it. It's a testament to his conning abilities. He's the greatest conman we've ever produced.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's it? That's the --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It was time, 12 seasons. We've been doing it for 24 years. I mean, it's a long time. And I don't know, do we really want to see an old guy on television just until his 80s. I mean, how long --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's too late. I'm already seeing --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, how long can you watch it? Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What are you going to do with yourself?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'll find some stuff. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In entertainment, or you're going to just play golf?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, no. I'll do something. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But "Curb"? And this is final? This is --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: This is it, Chris. This is it. I'm making a Shermanesque statement.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: If nominated you will not --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You started "Seinfeld" in 1989, and I want to play a clip from perhaps the most famous episode, the contest, that won you an Emmy, and "TV Guide," that great authority, said was the greatest episode of TV ever.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I want to be in on this, too.

utterances.speaker: SEINFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Why, why?

utterances.speaker: SEINFELD
utterances.sentences: Because you're woman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: So what.

utterances.speaker: SEINFELD
utterances.sentences: It's easier for a woman not to do it than a man. We have to do it. It's part of our lifestyle. It's like shaving.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: That is such baloney. I shave my legs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Not every day.(LAUGHTER) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So first of all, how did you come up with that idea?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I had a contest with a friend.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Literally?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Literally.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That contest?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That contest.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Who couldn't put it off longer?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. Had a contest.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And what were the results of said contest?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I was clearly the winner. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Really? What did you go, two days?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Anyway, that's where they came from.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And how much trouble did you have getting it passed the NBC censors?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Usually, the network would -- when they would come into the room after a show or after a run through, they would look at our board and see upcoming shows. And they'd say, what's that one about, what's that one about? And for "The Contest," I didn't put it up on the board because I didn't want them asking what it was about because I knew they wouldn't do it. They came to read through. They heard the show.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: And in my head, I'm going, well, if they don't let -- if they don't let us do this, I'm done. I'm quitting. As soon as they say no, we're not doing it. And I've gotten hold speech in my head.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Sorry, good luck. I'm done. That's what I was going to do. I was going to quit.But then we have the read through. It got great laughs. They came back to our office, and they didn't say a word. I was stunned.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Maybe a little disappointed, too? DAVID(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I missed out on a big dramatic moment.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So why do you think they let it go?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I don't know. I guess because they heard laughs. And when they hear laughs, it kind of changes their thinking about something.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: There's another episode I love in which George is trying to impress a girlfriend at a kids' birthday party.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Smoke. Everybody, I think I smell some smoke back here. Fire!(SCREAMING) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It was an inferno in there, an inferno!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There he is, that's him!(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Incidentally, was the clown with the big shoe, he's the one who put out the fire. After the clown and the kids and the old lady and the presumed girlfriend all come out and excoriate George, a fireman says, how do you live with yourself? And George says, it's not easy.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, and George is supposedly based on you, so same question. How do you live with yourself?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I like going to the office. I like playing golf. I like being in my house.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'm so dull and uninteresting. I really don't enjoy being out and socializing and making small talk. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is this a bit that you're doing for me?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, no, it's not a bit, it's not a bit. It's not a bit. Ask anybody who knows me. You know what, I wish it was a bit. I wish it was. I long to be somebody else. I wish I could enjoy things that most people enjoy. But I can't. Yes. I don't know. I mean, something went off somewhere.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Something went terribly wrong.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Something went wrong, Chris.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Speaking of things going wrong, you wrote for "Saturday Night Live" for one season.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: You've really done some background stuff.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes. And the story I heard is you're writing for "Saturday Night Live" an entire season. You get one sketch on the air.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you get so fed up that at one point, one night, you go to the executive producer and you say to him, I quit.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you realized overnight --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It was laced with profanity, by the way, the "I quit" speech.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It was one that I was going to deliver it to the "Seinfeld" -

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: About the contest. But this time --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: This time I actually did it. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. And then overnight, you realized this is a big mistake and that you show up for work on Monday pretending nothing ever happened?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is that a true story? DAVID

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And how did that go?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: It went well.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Did nobody say, hey, what are you doing here?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I got some odd looks from the writers, people who witnessed my meltdown. And the executive producer who was running it, didn't see it. He asked me what I was working on, and I told him, and then he moved on to the next person. I just sat there, and he went down the line of the writers, asked them what they were working on. Got to me, what are you working on? I told him, and then he went to the next one.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you turned this into a storyline for George.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: For George, yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Who quits, realizes it's a mistake, comes back to work, and --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You and I went to dinner with your lovely wife, Ashley.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Last fall, and you very nicely picked up the check. And the next day I wrote you, I thought, a very gracious "Thank you" note. And you then responded, and I have saved this. And I literally quoted this. You wrote back to me and you said, keep in mind, next time when you pick up the check, you will not be getting a next day thanks.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What's so objectionable --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: How many thank yous do we have to give out?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I gave one.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: No, I understand. But if you if you take me out to dinner and I say, hey, Chris, thank you so much. Why do I have to do -- where does it say I have to send something the next day? Why? Everybody is sending all these next day thank you texts. You thank somebody when you leave. That's enough.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I wanted to do it. I'm not asking you to send me a thank you note. I sent you a thank you note, but you had to respond to it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I know, because I just wanted you to know in advance that I wasn't going to send you a next day thank you text if you took me out to dinner the next time. I was going to thank you after the dinner, before I got in my car. Thanks so much. I really appreciate it. Thank you. thank you so much. Thank you. And that's sufficient. You don't need a next day text, do you? Why do you need the next day text?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I kind of would appreciate it. Because otherwise you've just gotten in the car, you've driven off, you've never given a second thought to me and how gracious I was.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: But I said, thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I understand. But it was a momentary thank you. It needs to at least last until the next day.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I think that's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So tell me something else.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: An everyday social interaction that kind of greases the wheels of humanity that you've think is stupid.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I mean, there's 12 seasons worth of it, like the "Happy New Year". I don't understand why anybody would say "Happy New Year" to me. I can't even respond to it on a text, "Happy New Year". Why? Why are you sending that to me? I don't care. I don't care about a new year. What's the difference? What's the difference? "Happy New Year", what does it even mean?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, there's even a better question, which I think was actually in one of your episodes. How long after January 1st do you have to keep saying "Happy New Year"? In other words --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, was nice and said January 7th, but now I'm revising that to January 3rd.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: January 3rd.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's it?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That's it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do people come up to you and sort of say, almost like a rabbi, how long do I have to say --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: They do?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you pronounce?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, and I have answers for all of them.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So January 3rd.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'm changing it to January 3rd, yes. Yes. And here's the thing, because I'm Jewish, I also get the "Happy New Year in September at the Rosh Hashanah.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, and I get it then. So I'm getting a twice a year.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's a nightmare.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I don't need it. Don't wish me "Happy New Year." I don't even care if you wish me happy birthday. What do you think about that?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, now we're really treading on sacred ground here.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Really? No, that's fine. "Happy Birthday" is fine. But, but, I've said this, and I think I did a movie where I talked about this, that the birthday is turned into a job. You're getting 25, 30 texts of "Happy Birthday". They all have to be answered. And it's a job.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, I agree with that, but here's the interesting question --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Do you agree that you have to respond to the "Happy Birthday" text? You have to say something.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You have to acknowledge it. If I send you a happy birthday and you don't respond, I consider it a snub.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Isn't it? It's a snub. In fact, I question the whole basis of our relationship.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes. So what I'm saying is I would rather not get the "Happy Birthday" text because I have to return it. That's all I'm saying. I'd rather not get it. If you want to say it in person if you see me, hey, happy birthday. Hey, thanks, happy birthday. But don't send me a text that I have to return. That's a job. No?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, I will say, and God forbid --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: So you're with me on the birthday?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do agree with you on the birthday, and I God forbid, it's a big birthday. Like you and I are almost exactly the same. I think you're like four months older than I am. And 75, a nightmare.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes. WALLACE

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Exactly. So if there's anything that I can do to change that --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'll sign up for that, as a matter of fact. You enlisted me.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: So you would rather -- let me get this straight now, you would rather people not say "Happy birthday," send you a text, a happy birthday text, because you have to return it, right? You agree?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, except that I have to say I'm a bit of a hypocrite because I do send people happy birthday texts. But guess what? After today, never again.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Or you could do this, "Happy birthday. No need whatsoever to reply to this happy birthday text."

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In fact, please don't.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: In fact, please don't. There you go.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, I want to ask you a question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Sure. Sure. What do you got?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Because my father always said people are fascinated by how much rich people are worth. I remembered him famously asking Johnny Carson once what he's worth.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That's a terrible, terrible question to ask Who does your father think he was, by the way?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We know.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes, we know. But still.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So here's the question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I hope, I hope that Johnny Carson said to him, Mike, none of your business. That's none of your business.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: He in effect said that. So here's the question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: On the Internet, I actually looked, the over-under is half-a- billion dollars. We're not doing a split here.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: By the way, I'm out of water, OK. I'm out.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You're out of water?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes. Is there anybody, can I get more water here? WALLACE

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: First of all, how dare you?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I've done 100 interviews --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: How dare you?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I've done 100 interviews and everybody takes that amount of water, and they pace themselves through the show. So that's it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Well, I didn't think we'd be going this long.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I think you're avoiding the question.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I'm avoiding the question? I'm going to say --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Over or under a half-a-bill dollars?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: -- what should have been said to your father, none of your -- business. How about that? And that's ridiculous. That's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: What you just said.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: A half-a-billion?

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: That number is so preposterous, OK. Ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How about $100 million.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: OK, how about you shut up, OK? How about you shut up? Is that all right?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I've got to say, you know, 100 interviews, nobody has ever said that to me before.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Just shut up.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. All right, we got that straight.Finally, I want to end with the "Seinfeld" finale in 1998. Here it is. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: JERRY SEINFELD, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: See now, to me that button is in the worst possible spot.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: SEINFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. The second button is the key button. It literally makes or breaks the shirt. Look at it. It's too high. It's in no man's land.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Haven't we had this conversation before?

utterances.speaker: SEINFELD
utterances.sentences: You think?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I think we have.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And 76 million people watched that. It was the sixth --

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: And 76 million disappointed people, yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm going to get to that.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It was the sixth most watched entertainment event on television at that time. And as you point out, some people weren't thrilled by that ending. What do you think of that ending? You wrote it.

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: I thought it was pretty good.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVID
utterances.sentences: Pretty, pretty, pretty, pretty good.(END VIDEO TAPE)
